summary: This Ewok Rice Bowl Will Make You Say 'Yub Nub! Ewoks: friend or foe? It depends on whether they’ve strung you up for a BBQ or...
caption:
This Ewok Rice Bowl Will Make You Say ‘Yub Nub!

Ewoks: friend or foe? It depends on whether they’ve strung you up for a BBQ or whether they think of you as some kind of god.

Still it’s hard to resist a furry face and sweet eyes, but instead of heading to the Endor moon, now you can make your own little Ewok pal at home — with an Ewok Rice Bowl! These flavorsome bowls are made with brown rice imbued with rich coconut milk, topped off with vegetables and fruit. In the end you’ll have a happy little rebel friend looking back at you.

When you’ve finished making this delightful dish, you’ll surely be accepted as part of the tribe. Check out how to make an Ewok Rice Bowl below. 

What You’ll Need:

  • inari (aburaage) tofu pockets, seasoned
  • Cherries
  • Plum
  • Kiwi
  • mushroom

Coconut brown rice ingredients:

  • 1 cup brown rice
  • 1 (14 ounce) can coconut milk
  • 1 cup water
  • Pinch of sugar
  • Pinch of salt

Step 1: Rinse the rice under water a few times, then drain completely.

Step 2: In a saucepan stir together the rice, coconut milk, water, sugar, and salt. Bring to a boil.

Step 3: Reduce heat and cover, then simmer for 18 minutes.

Step 4: Fluff with a fork, then scoop into a bowl, reserving approximately ½ cup.

Step 5: Separate the inari and place around the edges of the bowl, leaving an empty center area.

Step 6: Add the rest of the brown rice on the sides for the ears.

Step 7: Cut a cherry to create the nose, and carve two small ovals out of the plum for the eyes.

Step 8: Slice the mushroom to form the mouth.

Step 9: Cut strips of kiwi to add the details to the cowl.

Step 10: Once everything is in place the bowl is ready to serve. Yub nub!

Recipe by Jenn Fujikawa

summary: To say Mon Mothma didn't learn from the mistakes of the Old Republic isn't completely true as she did several things to ensure...
question: To say Mon Mothma didn't learn from the mistakes of the Old Republic isn't completely true as she did several things to ensure the New Republic is neither a continuation of the Old Republic nor the Empire. Rotating the capital around to prevent complacence and detachment, making sure all member planets have an equal say and distributing reconstruction efforts evenly after the GCW are all measures that can be credited to her. The most glaring error she made was the demilitarisation of the 1/2
answer:
2/2 central military while the Imperial Remnants still exist and are a threat. There is also the fact discussed by Leia and Han that while Mon Mothma was Chancellor, the NR did work and for a time seemed to be better than both the Old Republic and the Empire, yet it was Mon Mothma’s own charisma and negotiating skills which ensured an almost constant political consensus. Once she stepped down they had, according to Han, a bunch of utterly useless guys in charge which made the NR a farce.         

  Essentially, what the Star Wars galaxy needs is a type of government that unites the positive aspects of the Old Republic and the Empire, like the democratic, artistic and liberal aspects of the former, with guaranteed individual rights and freedom of speech and the centralized, sufficiently strong military and security laws (which don’t slide off into oppression) from the latter.  A democratic, free state does need the means to protect these freedoms, something the NR in the new canon forgot.      

 You know what would have been neat? If any of this was in the films. This political background stuff is neat and helps explain what the hell is going on. The fact that I have to buy and read, like, at least Bloodline and possibly the Aftermath series to know any of this genuinely pisses me off.

summary: "Star Wars: Episodio IX": Mostraron imagen del set de grabación
title: "Star Wars: Episodio IX": Mostraron imagen del set de grabación
body:
“Star Wars: Episodio IX”: Mostraron imagen del set de grabación

Aunque aún falta mucho tiempo para que podamos ver el nuevo episodio de la trilogía actual de Star Wars, han sido muchos los tropiezos que encuentra esta producción.

En primer lugar, “Star Wars: Episodio IX” se quedó sin director, y se incorporaron nuevas caras a la historia, pero la película ya está en producción.

Por su parte, el director de fotografía, Dan Mindel,publicó la primera imagen del…

View On WordPress

summary: For @michaelathewordsmith and an anon…based on the song Speak Now by Taylor Swift. Enjoy! You sat on a small ottoman, staring...
caption:
For @michaelathewordsmith and an anon…based on the song Speak Now by Taylor Swift. Enjoy!

You sat on a small ottoman, staring into space, while handmaidens and assigned groomsmen bustled about around you. The only thing you could focus on was the oncoming wedding…yours.

There was a particular reason you weren’t smiling or even fully participating in the process; you were in love with someone else. The Supreme Leader may have ordered you to marry his star pupil, but you were hardly compliant. Part of you thought he had figured out your relation with Armitage and tailored this punishment just for you.

I am not the kind of girl
Who should be rudely bargin’ in on a white veil occasion
But you are not the kind of boy
Who should be marryin’ the wrong girl

Hux watched from the shadows as he heard you scream at them to leave. He held back a laugh as they scattered from the room. When the coast was clear, he snuck into your room, locking the door behind you.

With a desperate urge, he pulled you toward him. Shocked, you let out a small yelp. After realizing it was him, you latched onto him as though he were air for your lungs.

“Armitage,” you breathed, a tear slipping.
“It’s alright,” he soothed, “I’m right here.”
“I don’t want to marry him,” you quivered, “I don’t want anyone else but you.”

Hux gulped, attempting to keep his ever reddening eyes from leaking. He could only think to hold you closer.

“Don’t say yes, run away now
I’ll meet you when you’re out
Of the church at the back door
Don’t wait or say a single vow
You need to hear me out”

Kylo Ren loomed just outside the hall. He needn’t hear the words since he felt the conflict through the Force. Part of him felt something for you, but he had resigned you to Hux a long time ago. The general wasn’t his favorite person, but he gave you happiness. 

…Maybe there was something he could do.

Perma-tags: @beeeeeeeeeeeeeeeep @ttelesilla @jumperswellies @caitsymichelle13 @frostbyte-horan @bestillmystuckyheart​ @littlestfangirl​ @anali-022506​ @krylo-rxn​ @ilovetvshowsblog​ @yllwtaxi @mimikyu-of-death @happy-days-22
Semi-tags: @bi-shy-and-ready-to-die

summary: Star Wars done right: The 15 best episodes of The Clone Wars
title: Star Wars done right: The 15 best episodes of The Clone Wars
excerpt: The stories this beloved animated series told remain some of the best in the franchise. Check out our favorites.
description: The Clone Wars defined an era of Star Wars never before seen. 10 years later, it still holds up as one of the best official canon entries.

reblog.comment: The Clone Wars defined an era of Star Wars never before seen. 10 years later, it still holds up as one of the best official canon entries.

blog.title: Star Wars AO3 Feed
blog.description:
An AO3 Feed for the Star Wars - All Media Types tag.

Icon from the Star Wars App.

title: I Know Your Name
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2KUMJUT

by Lady_Faulkner

Knowing a person’s True Name gives you absolute power over them and after the Battle of Craft, Kylo is determined to learn Hux’s. Unfortunately for him, Hux is not what he seems and saying his True Name unleashes a dark force that reshapes everything Kylo thought he knew about the General.

Words: 464, Chapters: ½, Language: English

  • Fandoms: Star Wars - All Media Types
